To the Public.

Ha

From the John Hull newspaper of Oct. 1 5 .

..jjy your leave, ye majors! Leviathans though
e be! you are not the only fish that swim, nor the
£ 0 S t dainty. And this week at least, your rank
Lust give place to the higher order of m e r i t T h e
little theatre in the Hay market may boast of havj„<r presented the public with many of the choicest
jomedles that g r rce the stage. H e r e FOOTE, COLh|Ajv, GOLDSMITH, J:ave in turn first triumphed;
[and broad satire, genuine humour, and playful wit
lmve endeared it as the seat of pleasant recollections. It h*ts remained for SHERJDAN KNOWLE8
|(o make it classic ground. T h e LOVE CHASE,
produced here on Monday, Oct. 9 , from the pen of
thin geii'lemaii, v» ill mark an epoch in its history,
as it jissuredly forms an e r a in modern dramatic
literature.
The acting of The LOVE CHASE is highly
•relished by the audience, a n d , combined with the
pleasure of hearing language at once so poetic and
racy. affords a treat w hich no one with pretensions
of love for the drama should grudge himself the
pleasure of seeing. W e should more than doubt
[his enthusiasm in behalf of a healthy literature and
la rational amusement, »vho would regret his money
[after the curtain fell."

Theatre Royal, Hay .Market,
mm

To the Public.
From the John Hull newspaper of Oct. 15.

"By your leave, ye majors ! Leviathans though
ye be! you are not the only fish that swim, nor the
most dainty. And this week at least, your rank
must give place to the higher order of merit. The
little theatre in the H a y market may boast of having presented the public with many of the choicest
comedies that gr,cce the stage. H e r e FooTE, COLMAN, GOLDSMITH, !:ave in turn first triumphed;
and broad satire, genuine humour, and playful wit
have endeared it as the seat ot pleasant recollections, i t has remained for S H E R I D A N K N O W L E S
lo make it classic ground. The LOVE CHASE,
produced here on Monday, Oct. 9 , from the pen of
this gen'leman, will mark an epoch in its history,
as it assuredly forms an e r a in modern dramatic
literature.
The acting of The LOVE CHASE is highly
relished by the audience, and, combined with the
pleasure of hearing language at once so poetic and
r
*cj, affords a treat which no one with pretensions
«f love for the drama should grudge himself the
pleasure of seeing. We should more than doubt
his enthusiasm in behalf of a healthy literature and
*' rational amusement, who would regret his money
»-W the curtain fell."

subservient tb h i s purpose. T h e plot is strongly pathetic.
There w«s miVeh applause bestowed 6» t h e play throughout it* ordeal, and a t Hie end Know les was culled forth
with gencVa' fit-claim."—.Vot-nin^ Herald,

and with the smiles that it provokes St blends a pathos
that comes direct from t h e moSl ' sacred fount of s j h i pathetic tears.' T h e natilral interests 6{ lis situations.
particular scenes of hhmoiir and pathos, tho poetical
diameter of t h e diction insure for it a popularity which
the author's exertions merit.
I t s announcement Tor
every evening was received with lood and unanimous
applause."—Morning
Chrontelt.
" As a tirarnatie work we like The Maid of Maricnrlorpi more than Hie 7-*ie Chate.
I t s plot is well
imagined', i t s interest well sustained, and its poetry in

" T h e discrimlHatidg jptiblic is again indebted t o Mr
Sheridan Know les for one of those sparkling emanations
of poetic genius which a r e impertshably interwoven with
his natrie Upon ' h e record* of our dramatic literature
The humanities never have been more delightfully p o u r trayed than in this play. I t is futl of passages of impassioned e l o q t i e h t e : and, as an effective drama appealing
to our most holy sympathies, we consider it superior t o
any oi his former productions " — W e e k l y
Chronicle,
" Tlie Maid of Martendorpi is worthy, of Mr. Knowles'
reputation a s a dramatic writer. I t sparkles with poetic
beauties throughout, while some of t h e scenes a r e
managed with t h e greatest dramatic skill, and is sure te
attain to great popularity."— The Ob*ener.
" T h e merit of The Maid of Mariendorpt
is so g r e a t ,
that no livin;; author save Know lis could have wutten i t ;
and it would b e difficult to point out anything on the
stage finer than.the whole of the fourth act. T h e g e t t i n g
up of the piay reflects the highest credit on the m a n a g e ment ; t h e dresses were admirable, and the whole of t h .
details carefully looked to. W e doubt not b u t every one
who values a national poet and a national drama, will g o
arid see The Maid of Mariendorpt', and give due honour*
• to the author."—Th* Age.
" T h e object of the dramatist h a s been to give a faithful
portrait of e*alted filial affection—-the affection of a
d a u g h t e r t o a beloved and indulgent parent
T h e maitr
ebd of the drama is ttt carry out and pourtray this b e a u tiful, this sublime feeling-"-*!! our sensibilities a r e
interested—nunc of oUr sense* excited—it is a play of tho
b e a n ahd St* mind
Another aim ha* been to break
dewh the barriers of prejudice between the Jew and t h e
Christian; arid t h e whole of these efforts are successful
through n vein of poetry which seems g u s h i n g from tho
fountain of the heart."—Tk* Era.
